metadata.title: A Comprehensive Guide on Activation Functions | by Ygor Serpa | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: A Comprehensive Guide on Activation Functions
metadata.description: Since 2012, the advances in neural network research have dominated most of the Artificial Intelligence (AI) literature, with models quickly taking over benchmarks on a wide variety of topics. At the…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: my affiliate link when signing up.

all_paragraphs: Since 2012, the advances in neural network research have dominated most of the Artificial Intelligence (AI) literature, with models quickly taking over benchmarks on a wide variety of topics. At the heart of these innovations, activation functions play a crucial role in the efficiency and stability of neural networks. In this article, the state-of-the-art in activation function research will be overview as briefly as possible, with a clear, practical focus on why they were invented and when they should be applied.
In short, activation functions address two critical problems in Neural Networks:

To understand the need for non-linear activation maps, consider the following two functions: f(x) = ax + b and g(x) = (c+d)x + (e + f). The former has only two constants, whereas the second has four. The question is: are they effectively two different functions?

The answer is no, “(c + d)” and “a” have the same expressive power. If you chose c = 10 and d = 2, I could choose a = 12, and we will reach the same result. The same goes for “(e + f)” and “b”. To effectively posses four independent parameters, they must not be combinable. In mathematical terms, this means that the relationship between the parameters must be non-linear. For instance, h(x) = sin(cx + d) + fx + e is a non-linear model with four parameters.

In neural networks, if layers were linear, two consecutive layers would be combinable. Hence, they would effectively be just a single layer in disguise. To not be linear, all layers are passed into non-linear functions, such as the ReLU and Tanh functions, isolating them into individually functioning units.

When answering yes or no questions, such as “there is a face or not in an image,” false is modeled as zero and true as one. Given an image, if the network output is 0.88, we say the network answered true, as 0.88 is closer to one than to zero. However, the output of a network can be 2 or -7. How can we guarantee that its answer will be in the [0, 1] range?

For that, several activation functions have been devised to guarantee some numerical properties. For the binary classification case, the sigmoid function (σ(x)) takes inputs in the range [-∞, ∞] and outputs values in the [0, 1] range. Likewise, the hyperbolic tangent function (tanh(x)) maps [-∞, ∞] to [-1, 1]. For one-hot encoded categorical data, the softmax function squeezes all values to the [0, 1] interval and ensures that they all add up to one.

Typically these “numerical properties” activations are used in the last layer of the network, known as the output layer, as this is usually the only layer that warrants special treatment. For all others, simpler non-linearities are used, such as the ReLU family. While there are cases in which special activations are needed in the middle of the network, such as used on object detection models and attention layers, these are not the norm and are out of the scope of this article.

In the previous section, we saw why activations are needed and which problems they solve. Moreover, we noticed that all layers require activation functions to be independent, but only a few require special features. For all ordinary layers, activations from the ReLU family are typically used.

Before going into the dirty details, I would like to highlight that, within the realm of ReLU-like activations, there is not much problem-specific rationale for using one over the other. In practice, people just try them out on a loop for a dozen epochs to see which performs best on their task.

That said, a rule of thumb is to stick with the original ReLU activation for as long as possible during development and, if your model is not performing well, skip to the SELU activation follow the recommendations given in the Tensorflow 2 Docs (even for PyTorch users) and get rid of all batch normalizations. I know this sounds a bit harsh, but it works and may give you a solid 5% to 10% boost.
For a summary, the following image sums up the most well-known activations from the ReLU family, with their plots (left) and their performance on the CIFAR-10 dataset (right).
The mathematical definition of the rectifier is:
In English, if positive, return x, if negative, return 0.

This is one of the simplest non-linearity possible; computing the max function is as simple as it can get. One of the earlier uses of the ReLU function comes from the AlexNet architecture, which trained almost eight times faster using this activation, over the more traditional Tanh function. For this reason, to this day, the ReLU family of activations is the de-facto choice for most layers, as they are computationally simple, yet effective. A win-win scenario.

Additionally, early neural networks were plagued by a problem known as the exploding/vanishing gradients. In sum, during backpropagation, gradients are multiplied with each other as you move back into the network, so large gradients with large gradients explode the signal while near-zero gradients with near-zero gradients vanish it. Using the ReLU activation, there are only two possible gradients: one, for the positive part, and zero, for the negative one. Therefore, concerning the role of activation functions on the problem, the rectifier effectively solves the exploding issue, which is arguably the worse, while creating the dead gradients problem.

The first concern most people raise when seeing the ReLU function for the first time is: is the negative part really being thrown away? Yes, it is. Puzzled by it, researchers proposed the LeakyReLU. Instead of throwing away the negative part, return a diminished version of it. Mathematically:

This way, the signal is not completely lost, but significantly diminished by a leak factor. In practice, this proved effective in some scenarios. Also, it alleviates the dead gradient problem, allowing at least some part of the signal to go through. Playing with the negative part is a recurring theme over the next activations.

The next iteration was the Parametric ReLU, or PReLU, for short. The rationale was: why 0.01? Instead, let us introduce an α variable and let it be trainable. This way, we do not need to define the leak factor ourselves; we let the network learn the most appropriate value by itself. In expression form:

Keep in mind that the α variable is not global. Each unit has its trainable α. This activation demonstrates the data-science way of thinking: why set things up yourself if you can let the model decide what is best?

Continuing the pursuit for better performing activations, the idea of using the exponential function for the negative part came about in late 2015. The exponential function is saturating for negative values, which means it smoothly tends towards a fixed constant. Using it, we can more closely simulate the original ReLU function, which saturates at zero, while still retaining the negative portion to some extent. Here is its mathematical formulation:
In many cases, the ELU function is a clear improvement over the original ReLU function. In contrast, the leaky variants are not as consistently better.

One of the most recent advances in this field is called the Scaled Exponential Linear Unit, or SELU, and its major innovation is being self-normalizing. This means that, when trained, it will converge towards outputting results with zero mean and unit variance. In practice, this renders batch normalization layers obsolete. Therefore, models using SELU activations are simpler and need fewer operations. Finally, the self normalizing property is accomplished by simply scaling the positive and negative parts by magical constants. Formally:

For more details on using this activation function and on the derivation of the magical constants, consider reading the paper and the Tensorflow Docs. The constants mentioned above were obtained by simplifying the original SELU expression into a more compact form.

So far, all activations from the ReLU family are monotonically increasing. In English, this means that the function values only ever grow. Iconic non-monotonic functions are the parabola (x²), which goes down them up, and the sine function (sin(x)), which goes up and down periodically.
The first successful proposal of a non-monotonic activation is the Swish function, by the Google Brain team, and is simply defined as:

Being σ(x) the sigmoid function. While this expression does not resemble the ReLU function, their plots are significantly similar, with a near-identity positive part, a negative part saturating at zero, and a “dip” or “belly” near zero at the negative side (Figure 1, in blue). This is achieved by a “self-gating” mechanism. Basically, x is the “signal,” σ(x) is a “gating function” (a function that saturates at zero), and applying σ to x and multiplying by x is taking the signal and gating it by itself, thus, a self-gating operation. In the team experiments, they have found that this activation is superior to the ReLU function for very deep networks (30+ layers).

Finally, the SERLU activation is an improvement over the SELU function, retaining the self-normalizing property while including a self-gating mechanism to saturate at zero for negative values. The authors accomplish this by using the exponential function as the gating operation, instead of the sigmoid, and recalculating the magic constants. This leads to a large “dip” in the negative side of the function, similar to the Swish function, but more pronounced (Figure 1, in red). Formally, the SERLU is defined as:
Take note of the similarity between x ⋅ eˣ and x ⋅ σ(x). Both are self-gating mechanisms.

As of 2020, it is too early to tell whether these non-monotonic functions will endure the test of time and replace the ReLU or SELU as a good general-purpose alternative. However, if I may, I would bet that the self-normalizing property is here to stay.

As previously said, some layers require special treatment beyond what ReLU-like activations can give. For these layers, the linear, sigmoid, tanh, and softmax activations are used, and their use-cases are:

As you can see, given a problem, it is straightforward to pick which activation you should use. Additionally, the chosen function hints on which loss functions should be used/considered. Although this is a simplification, it is useful as a starting point. As mentioned before, a rule of thumb is to use the ReLU activation throughout, pick the most appropriate special function for the last layer, and, on later iterations, expand on these initial choices and try alternative formulations.

As a final note, it is worth mentioning that, for some problems, classes are not mutually exclusive. In this special case, a single input might be labeled with more than one class. In those cases, the sigmoid is used per-class, instead of the softmax activation. This way, all outputs are squeezed to the [0, 1] range, but they are not enforced to add up to one.

In this article, the state-of-the-art in activation functions was reviewed, with practical guidance on which to use and why. In summary, activations are used to make the networks non-linear and to enforce special properties to the output layers. For internal layers, the ReLU family is used, and, as a rule of thumb, stick with the ReLU activation for as long as possible, then switch to the SELU activation and remove all batch normalization operations. For the output layers, consider using the linear/tanh activations for unnormalized/normalized regression and the sigmoid/softmax for binary/categorical classification.

As in any guide, something will always be missing. Here, I deliberately skipped lesser-known/used choices, such as the softplus, softsign, and relu6 functions. I have chosen to do so to keep the article as brief as possible, without compromising the popular ones. If you missed any activation function being discussed, disagree on something or would like to see some concept expanded, please let me know in the comments section and I will do my best to keep this document up-to-date :)

Feel free to comment or connect with me if you have any questions on this article. If you are new to Medium, I highly recommend subscribing. Medium articles are the perfect pair to StackOverflow for Data and IT professionals, and even more so for new comers. Please consider using my affiliate link when signing up.
Former game developer turned data scientist after falling in love with AI and all its branches.
